answers: René Descartes

method [accept scientific method; or Discourse on Method; or Discourse on the Method of Rightly Conducting One’s Reason and of Seeking Truth in the Sciences; or Discours de la Méthode Pour bien conduire sa raison, et chercher la vérité dans les sciences]
architecture [or building; accept town or urban planning]
parts: Name this philosopher who had those dreams while sleeping next to an oven in Ulm, Germany. In a later work, he wondered whether he could be dreaming about sitting next to a fire in his dressing gown.
Descartes described the influence that his night in Ulm had on his philosophy in a “Discourse on” this concept. Francis Bacon formulated the “scientific” type of this process.

Descartes’s revelations on that night began with the observation that, like laws, works in this field are better when created by a single person. Descartes also compared his method to a person in this field digging trenches in sand.

answers: inalienable possession [prompt on alienability]
kinship terminology [or kin terminology; prompt on familial relationships or family members]

transitive verbs [prompt on transitivity] (The phenomenon in the first clue doesn’t apply in English, but in Spanish, for example, “Me corté el dedo” is grammatical while “Me corté mi dedo” is not. This is because “dedo” is understood to be obligatorily possessed by the implied subject, “yo.”)
parts: Name this cross-linguistic category of obligatorily-possessed nouns. Body parts are frequently members of this closed class of nouns, which become morpho-syntactically marked when non-possessed.

Besides body parts, this is the other common class of inalienable nouns. Lewis Henry Morgan divided systems of terminology for this concept into six types, which may include affinal (“uh-final”) relations.

In many languages, inalienable nouns take definite articles instead of possessive articles when they are the objects of verbs with this property. Unlike “eat,” “devour” is obligatorily one of these verbs, since it requires an object.

answers: Bob Marley [or Bob Marley; or the Singer]
Marlon James
Jamaica
parts: Name this character who survives being shot by a group of gunmen led by Josey Wales. This man manages to broker peace between Papa-Lo and the don of the Eight Lanes in a 2014 novel.
This contemporary author of The Book of Night Women and Black Leopard, Red Wolf fictionalized the attempted assassination of Bob Marley in his A Brief History of Seven Killings.
A Brief History of Seven Killings is mostly set in this home country of Marlon James and Bob Marley.

answers: malate–aspartate shuttle [prompt on malate shuttle]

oxidative phosphorylation [or OXPHOS; accept chemiosmosis; accept electron transport chain, electron transport system, ETC, or ETS; prompt on cellular respiration; do not accept or prompt on “Krebs cycle” or “TCA cycle”]
oxaloacetate [or oxaloacetic acid; or OAA]
parts: Name this system that transports electrons generated by glycolysis into the mitochondria by cycling its two namesake molecules. One of those molecules is antiported against alpha-ketoglutarate; the other, against glutamate.
The mitochondria uses NADH supplied by the malate–aspartate shuttle as the main reducing equivalent in this process. During this process, a proton gradient powers the generation of ATP from ADP.

In the malate shuttle, malate dehydrogenase interconverts malate with this molecule, which then binds an amino group to yield aspartate. This molecule and acetyl-CoA (“uh-SEE-til co-A”) react in the Krebs cycle’s first step to yield citrate.

answers: Olmec civilization [or Olmecs]
were-jaguars [prompt on jaguars]
Zapotec civilization [or Zapotecs]
parts: Name this civilization whose major archaeological sites include San Lorenzo and La Venta. Jade facsimiles of their iconic colossal heads were found amongst the Mayans.

The prevalence of this motif, which depicts a cleft head with turned lips, provides evidence for the mother culture hypothesis. It is named for a fusion of humans with a certain animal, as theorized by Mathew Stirling.

Were-jaguars and fire-serpents were extensively uncovered at the site of San Jose Mogote, considered to be the origin of this civilization. Its grand city of Monte Alban (“MON-tay AHL-bahn”) features courts for playing ball game.

answers: Dictionary of the Khazars [or Dictionary of the Khazars: A Lexicon Novel; or Hazarski rečnik]
The Bridge on the Drina [or Na Drini ćuprija]
Islam [or Muslims; accept specific answers like Shia or Sunni Islam]
parts: Name this Serbian novel by Milorad Pavić (“PA-veech”), which comes in “male” and “female” versions that differ in one crucial passage. It purportedly consists of three encyclopedias, one for each Abrahamic religion.
In this other Serbian novel by Ivo Andrić (“EE-voh AHN-drich”), a man has his ear nailed to the title structure, which Mehmed Paša Sokolović builds on the place he was taken from his mother.

In The Bridge on the Drina, Mehmed is forced to convert from Christianity to this faith, which names the middle part of Dictionary of the Khazars. The central family in Palace Walk and Sugar Street practices this religion.

answers: requiem [or requiem mass; accept A German Requiem]
György Ligeti (“JURJ LIG-uh-tee”)
“O Magnum Mysterium” [or “O Great Mystery”]
parts: A Lux Aeterna section is sometimes included in this type of work, which sets to music a liturgy for the dead. Johannes Brahms wrote a “German” one of these pieces.

This composer used micropolyphony in his Lux Aeterna. He also wrote a set of piano pieces called Musica Ricercata (“ree-chair-KA-ta”), whose first movement consists almost exclusively of the pitch “A.”

Another Lux Aeterna was written by American composer Morton Lauridsen, who is better known for this motet with a text describing Christ’s Nativity. Tomás Luis de Victoria also wrote a motet with this title.

answers: herms [or hermai; or herma; or hermes; accept “mutilation of the herms”]
Sicilian Expedition [accept, but DO NOT REVEAL, Athens’s campaign in Sicily during the Peloponnesian War, or equivalents; prompt on Siege of Syracuse]
Second Peloponnesian War [do not accept or prompt on “First Peloponnesian War”]
parts: Name these pillars that were capped by a bust and, if male, given genitals. Unknown culprits, perhaps from a hetaireia, defaced these sacred statues just before an important campaign, scaring the superstitious populace.

The herms were mutilated shortly before this campaign, which eventually resulted in the recall of Alcibiades, its primary advocate and leader. Command was then given to Nicias, who had opposed this campaign from the start.
The Sicilian Expedition occurred during this war. In this war, Sparta and its allies defeated the forces of the Delian League, which was led by Athens.

answers: Zechariah [or Zachariah or Zachary or Zacharias; accept Zechariah ben Johoiada]
John the Baptist [prompt on John]
golden calf [or golden calves; prompt on calf or calves; prompt on idols or statues]
parts: Name this eleventh minor prophet, whose namesake book predicts Christ’s entry into Jerusalem on a donkey. A priest with the same name became mute due to his disbelief towards a prophecy foretelling his wife’s pregnancy.
Zechariah was also the name of the father of this cousin of Jesus, who baptized Christ in the Jordan River.

Yet another Biblical figure named Zechariah was the son of King Jeroboam, who created two of these objects at Bethel and Dan. Earlier, Moses forced the Israelites to drink the powdered remains of one of these objects.

answers: differential scanning calorimetry [or DSC; prompt on calorimetry]
phase transitions [or phase changes; or state changes; prompt on partial answer]
power [accept power-compensated DSC or power-compensation DSC]
parts: Name this technique that linearly increases the temperature of both a reference material and a sample, measuring the disparity in heat capacity between them.
Differential scanning calorimetry can measure properties like enthalpy of vaporization, making it useful for detecting these phenomena. These general physical phenomena include melting and freezing.
DSC has two main types: heat-flux DSC, in which one furnace heats both the sample and the reference, and a type in which this quantity is “compensated” between separate sample and reference furnaces.

answers: Stephen Crane (The collection is The Black Riders.)

The Changing Light at Sandover [prompt on “Voices from the Other World” or “The Book of Ephraim” or Divine Comedies or Mirabell: Books of Number or Scripts for the Pageant by asking “which larger work were they part of?”] (by James Merrill)
Ezra Pound
parts: Name this author who wrote about a creature eating his heart “because it is bitter / And because it is my heart” in that collection. This author also wrote “Do not weep, maiden, for war is kind.”
In this 560-page poem, all caps are used to represent lines like “IF… U GIVE ME… HA HA YR SOULS” from the voices of spirits like Ephraim, Mirabell, and “God B” speaking to “DJ” and “JM.”
This Imagist author repeatedly capitalized the word “USURA” in an antisemitic section of his modernist epic, The Cantos.

answers: Einstein on the Beach
Philip Glass
on the roof [or equivalents; accept 1000 Airplanes On the Roof; accept The Ox on the Roof: The Nothing-Doing Bar or Le bœuf sur le toit]
parts: Name this opera in which lines like “These are the days my friends” intersperse a chorus of counting numbers. A bus driver narrates a story of love at the end of one of this opera’s five “Knee Plays.”
Einstein on the Beach was written by this American composer of the operas Satyagraha and Akhnaten.

In a one-person Philip Glass opera titled for “1000 Airplanes” in one of these locations, the narrator describes meeting aliens. A Brazilian-influenced ballet by Darius Milhaud (“dar-YOOS mee-YO”) is titled for a certain farm animal in this location.

answers: Hungary [or People’s Republic of Hungary; or Magyarorszag]
picnics [accept Pan-European Picnic]
Round Table Talks [or Round Table Agreements]
parts: Name this country. At the end of communist rule in this country, Imre Nagy (“EEM-ray NAWJ”), who had fought for democracy in this country in 1956, was reburied.

Hungarian communism ended following one of these events in which Hungarians and East Germans charged a fence on the Austrian border. Gyula Horn cut that fence during the “Pan-European” one of these events in 1989.
After the picnic, democracy came about through one of these orderly discussions in 1989. The Hungarian version of these events were inspired by ones organized by Solidarity in Poland.

answers: plasma [accept plasma oscillations or plasma frequency]
Peter Debye (“duh-BYE”) [or Peter Joseph William Debye; accept Debye sheath or Debye length]

square root of “kT over m” [or “kT over m” all to the one-half power; or equivalents of √(kT/m); accept answers with k times T in place of “kT”; accept answers with divided by or upon in place of “over”]
parts: Name this type of substance. Ignoring thermal effects, electron oscillations in this substance give their name to a frequency equal to [read slowly] the square root of “e-squared n over epsilon-naught times m-sub-e.”

The aforementioned sheath, and the length scale on which plasmas screen out charge imbalances, are both named for this Dutch physicist. He also gives his name to a common unit of electric dipole moment.

By the Bohm sheath criterion, ions entering a Debye sheath have a speed greater than a limit that depends only on Boltzmann’s constant k, the temperature T, and the ion mass m. Give that limit, in terms of k, T, and m.

answers: Rakhsh
Rostam [or Rustam] (Rostam recognizes the bracelet after killing his son, Sohrab.)
Shahnameh [or the Book of Kings]
parts: Name this horse who kills a lion during the first of seven trials in the course of defeating Div-e-Sepid (“DEEV-eh-seh-PEED”). This horse perishes alongside his master due to Shaghad’s treachery.

This hero tames Rakhsh and continually rescues Kay Kavus (“kai ka-VOOSE”). This hero meets Princess Tahmina when Rakhsh disappears on a hunting trip, and belatedly recognizes the bracelet he left with Tahmina after breaking a hero’s back.
Rakhsh and Rostam appear in this national epic of Iran, written by Ferdowsi.

answers: tiptoeing offstage [or creeping offstage; or leaving the stage quietly; or equivalents; prompt on exiting the stage or equivalents]
Noël Coward (The play is Blithe Spirit.)
Agatha Christie
parts: Name this action that characters do at the end of several comedies by a certain playwright. At the end of another such play, Amanda and Elyot do this action as their respective spouses argue violently with each other.

This author of Present Laughter and Private Lives often ended his plays by having characters tiptoe away from a chaotic situation. In a play by this author, Madame Arcati summons Charles’s dead wife Elvira at a séance (“SAY-once”).

Coward’s play Blithe Spirit set the record for the longest-ever run at the West End, a record that has since been broken by this author’s play The Mousetrap. This author also wrote And Then There Were None.

answers: veil [accept Veiled Christ or the Veil of Isis; accept shroud] (Corradini’s Modesty also stands in the Sansevero Chapel; a woman wearing the “Veil of Isis” is often used as a visual metaphor for Nature.)
kissing [accept The Kiss or Il Bacio or Le Baiser] (See Pietro Rossi and Raffaelle Monti’s veiled women; the last clue refers to Brâncuși’s The Kiss.)
Gian Lorenzo Bernini
parts: Name these objects. Antonio Corradini’s sculpture of a woman wearing one of these objects for the chapel might refer to a metaphorical one, for which Pierre Hadot (“ah-DOH”) titled an essay “On the History of the Idea of Nature.”

The Risorgimento was allegorized by veiled women in sculpture, as well as paintings of this action at the foot of some stairs by Francesco Hayez. Proto-Cubist limestone blocks depict this action in another work.
This Baroque sculptor created Truth Unveiled by Time after he was blamed for cracks in a pair of towers. His Ecstasy of St. Teresa features a backdrop of gilded rays.

answers: First Battle of Bull Run [or First Battle of Manassas; prompt on Battle of Bull Run or Manassas; do not accept or prompt on “Second Battle of Bull Run” or “Second Battle of Manassas”]
Johnstown Flood [or Great Flood of 1889]
noble [accept Henry Knox’s “noble train of artillery”]
parts: Stone Bridge was a site of fierce fighting during this first major battle of the Civil War. Barnard Bee gave Thomas Jackson the nickname “Stonewall” during this battle.

At least 80 people were killed when the Stone Bridge caught on fire during this disaster. Because Philander Knox argued that this disaster was an Act of God, the South Fork Fishing and Hunting Club paid no damages.
In a major logistical feat, Henry Knox led an artillery train, famously described by this adjective, over Stone’s Bridge while hauling guns from Fort Ticonderoga to Boston.

answers: Tycho Brahe [or Tyge Ottesen Brahe]
Gaia
photographic plates [or glass plates; accept plate solving; prompt on photographs or negatives; do not accept or prompt on “photographic film”]
parts: Name this Danish astronomer. Johannes Kepler used data from this man’s Uraniborg observatory to arrive at more accurate conclusions about planetary motion.

In the 1990s, the Hipparcos space telescope made the first large-scale survey of stellar parallaxes. This successor to Hipparcos offers vastly improved resolution, reporting parallaxes to within 7 microarcseconds (“micro-arc-seconds”).

To compute parallaxes, one must align a star field with positions in a star catalogue, a task sometimes named for “solving” these physical objects. Blink comparators once allowed users to visually compare two of these things.

answers: Douglas Engelbart
TCP [or Transmission Control Protocol; accept TCP/IP]
Bill Gates [or William Henry Gates III]
parts: Name this human–computer interaction engineer who invented the computer mouse.

Typing the “lo” in “login” crashed the first demo of ARPANET, which adopted this transport-layer protocol on “flag day.” This protocol is more robust than UDP and uses a three-way handshake with SYN (“sin”) and ACK (“ack”) flags.
In probably the most embarrassing tech demo ever, this founder of Microsoft triggered the Blue Screen of Death while attempting to show off Windows 98.
